answer_llm:
If you get "Allocator ran out of memory" errors while running TensorFlow on your machine, you can try adding the following code at the beginning of your notebook to adjust the GPU memory allocation:

```python
config = tf.compat.v1.ConfigProto()
config.gpu_options.allow_growth = True
session = tf.compat.v1.Session(config=config)
```

This approach has helped resolve similar issues for others. Note that while it may fix most of the problems, there could still be occasional instances of the error. If you encounter it again, simply re-running the code may help.
answer_orig:
If you are running tensorflow on your own machine and you start getting the following errors:
Allocator (GPU_0_bfc) ran out of memory trying to allocate 6.88GiB with freed_by_count=0. The caller indicates that this is not a failure, but this may mean that there could be performance gains if more memory were available.
Try adding this code in a cell at the beginning of your notebook:
config = tf.compat.v1.ConfigProto()
config.gpu_options.allow_growth = True
session = tf.compat.v1.Session(config=config)
After doing this most of my issues went away. I say most because there was one instance when I still got the error once more, but only during one epoch. I ran the code again, right after it finished, and I never saw the error again.
Added by Martin Uribe
question: What should I do if I get Allocator ran out of memory errors while running TensorFlow on my machine?

answer_llm:
To configure TensorFlow to solve memory allocation issues on your machine, you can use the following code snippet at the beginning of your notebook:

```python
config = tf.compat.v1.ConfigProto()
config.gpu_options.allow_growth = True
session = tf.compat.v1.Session(config=config)
```

This approach helps to manage GPU memory more effectively, and it resolved most of the memory allocation errors in similar scenarios. Additionally, if you are using an Nvidia GPU, you can also try this snippet:

```python
physical_devices = tf.config.list_physical_devices('GPU')
try:
    tf.config.experimental.set_memory_growth(physical_devices[0], True)
except:
    # Invalid device or cannot modify virtual devices once initialized.
    pass
```

These configurations will help in handling the memory allocation issues you might be facing with TensorFlow.

question: What code can I add to my notebook to address Allocator ran out of memory errors?

answer_llm: The solution for the Allocator ran out of memory errors in the FAQ record was added by Martin Uribe.
answer_orig:
If you are running tensorflow on your own machine and you start getting the following errors:
Allocator (GPU_0_bfc) ran out of memory trying to allocate 6.88GiB with freed_by_count=0. The caller indicates that this is not a failure, but this may mean that there could be performance gains if more memory were available.
Try adding this code in a cell at the beginning of your notebook:
config = tf.compat.v1.ConfigProto()
config.gpu_options.allow_growth = True
session = tf.compat.v1.Session(config=config)
After doing this most of my issues went away. I say most because there was one instance when I still got the error once more, but only during one epoch. I ran the code again, right after it finished, and I never saw the error again.
Added by Martin Uribe
question: Who added the solution for the Allocator ran out of memory errors in the FAQ record?

answer_llm:
When creating the virtual environment in session 10.3 with pipenv and trying to run the script gateway.py, you might encounter the following error:

**TypeError: Descriptors cannot not be created directly.**

This occurs if the version of protobuf in use is one of the newer ones, and you will need to ensure that your generated code is up to date by regenerating it with protoc >= 3.19.0. If you're unable to regenerate your protos, you can consider these workarounds:

1. Downgrade the protobuf package to 3.20.x or lower.
2. Set `PROTOCOL_BUFFERS_PYTHON_IMPLEMENTATION=python` (note that this will use pure-Python parsing and will be much slower).
answer_orig:
In session 10.3, when creating the virtual environment with pipenv and trying to run the script gateway.py, you might get this error:
TypeError: Descriptors cannot not be created directly.
If this call came from a _pb2.py file, your generated code is out of date and must be regenerated with protoc >= 3.19.0.
If you cannot immediately regenerate your protos, some other possible workarounds are:
1. Downgrade the protobuf package to 3.20.x or lower.
2. Set PROTOCOL_BUFFERS_PYTHON_IMPLEMENTATION=python (but this will use pure-Python parsing and will be much slower).
More information: https://developers.google.com/protocol-buffers/docs/news/2022-05-06#python-updates
This will happen if your version of protobuf is one of the newer ones. As a workaround, you can fix the protobuf version to an older one. In my case I got around the issue by creating the environment with:
pipenv install --python 3.9.13 requests grpcio==1.42.0 flask gunicorn \
keras-image-helper tensorflow-protobuf==2.7.0 protobuf==3.19.6
Added by Ángel de Vicente
question: What error might occur when creating the virtual environment in session 10.3 with pipenv and running gateway.py?

answer_llm:
To resolve the TypeError issue caused by the recent version of protobuf in session 10.3, you can take the following steps:

1. **Downgrade the protobuf package**: You can downgrade protobuf to version 3.20.x or lower. For example, you can run:
   ```
   pipenv install protobuf==3.20.1
   ```

2. **Set an environment variable**: Alternatively, you can set the environment variable `PROTOCOL_BUFFERS_PYTHON_IMPLEMENTATION=python`. However, keep in mind that this will use pure-Python parsing, which is slower.

If you are able to, you should also consider regenerating your protos with protoc version 3.19.0 or higher if your generated code is out of date.

answer_llm: If WSL cannot connect to the Docker daemon, you can try the following solution: Go to your Docker Desktop settings, click on "Resources," and then select "WSL Integration." Enable the additional distros, even if it is the same as the default WSL distro. This should help re-establish the connection to the Docker daemon.
answer_orig:
Due to the uncertainties associated with machines, sometimes you can get the error message like this when you try to run a docker command:
”Cannot connect to the Docker daemon at unix:///var/run/docker.sock. Is the docker daemon running?”
Solution: The solution is simple. The Docker Desktop might no longer be connecting to the WSL Linux distro. What you need to do is go to your Docker Desktop setting and then click on resources. Under resources, click on WSL Integration. You will get a tab like the image below:
Just enable additional distros. That’s all. Even if the additional distro is the same as the default WSL distro.
Odimegwu David
question: What should I do if WSL cannot connect to the Docker daemon?

answer_llm:
To resolve the error "Cannot connect to the Docker daemon at unix:///var/run/docker.sock. Is the Docker daemon running?", you can follow these solutions:

1. If you are using WSL (Windows Subsystem for Linux), you should re-install Docker. Remove the existing Docker installation from WSL and install Docker Desktop on your host machine (Windows).

2. If you are on Linux, you can start the Docker daemon using one of the following commands:
   - `sudo dockerd`
   - `sudo service docker start`

3. In some cases, Docker Desktop might not be connecting to the WSL Linux distro. You can go to your Docker Desktop settings, click on "Resources", then "WSL Integration", and enable any additional distros listed there.

Make sure to check these options based on your environment to successfully connect to the Docker daemon.

answer_llm:
If the HPA instance doesn't work correctly even after installing the latest Metrics Server, you can try the following solutions:

1. **Modify the Metrics Server Deployment**: Run the command:
   ```
   kubectl edit deploy -n kube-system metrics-server
   ```
   Then search for the line:
   ```
   args:
   - --kubelet-preferred-address-types=InternalIP,ExternalIP,Hostname
   ```
   Add the following line in the middle:
   ```
   - --kubelet-insecure-tls
   ```
   Your args section should look like this after the change:
   ```
   args:
   - --kubelet-insecure-tls
   - --kubelet-preferred-address-types=InternalIP,ExternalIP,Hostname
   ```
   Save and then run:
   ```
   kubectl get hpa
   ```

2. **Use an alternative Metrics Server deployment file**: You can also apply the following command, which uses a metrics server deployment file that already includes the `--kubelet-insecure-tls` option:
   ```
   kubectl apply -f https://raw.githubusercontent.com/Peco602/ml-zoomcamp/main/10-kubernetes/kube-config/metrics-server-deployment.yaml
   ```

These steps should help resolve the issue with the HPA instance not functioning correctly.
answer_orig:
In case the HPA instance does not run correctly even after installing the latest version of Metrics Server from the components.yaml manifest with:
>>kubectl apply -f https://github.com/kubernetes-sigs/metrics-server/releases/latest/download/components.yaml
And the targets still appear as <unknown>
Run >>kubectl edit deploy -n kube-system metrics-server
And search for this line:
args:
- --kubelet-preferred-address-types=InternalIP,ExternalIP,Hostname
Add this line in the middle:  - --kubelet-insecure-tls
So that it stays like this:
args:
- --kubelet-insecure-tls
- --kubelet-preferred-address-types=InternalIP,ExternalIP,Hostname
Save and run again >>kubectl get hpa
Added by Marilina Orihuela

answer_llm:
To fix the targets appearing as <unknown> in your HPA instance, you can take the following steps:

1. First, ensure you have installed the latest version of Metrics Server using the following command:
   ```bash
   kubectl apply -f https://github.com/kubernetes-sigs/metrics-server/releases/latest/download/components.yaml
   ```

2. If the targets still appear as <unknown>, you can edit the Metrics Server deployment:
   ```bash
   kubectl edit deploy -n kube-system metrics-server
   ```
   Find the line with:
   ``` 
   args:
   - --kubelet-preferred-address-types=InternalIP,ExternalIP,Hostname
   ```
   Add the following line in the middle:
   ```
   - --kubelet-insecure-tls
   ```
   So that it looks like this:
   ```
   args:
   - --kubelet-insecure-tls
   - --kubelet-preferred-address-types=InternalIP,ExternalIP,Hostname
   ```
   Save your changes and check the HPA again with:
   ```bash
   kubectl get hpa
   ```

3. Alternatively, you can use an easier solution by applying a predefined metrics server deployment file that already includes the `--kubelet-insecure-tls` option:
   ```bash
   kubectl apply -f https://raw.githubusercontent.com/Peco602/ml-zoomcamp/main/10-kubernetes/kube-config/metrics-server-deployment.yaml
   ```

By following these steps, you should be able to resolve the issue of targets appearing as <unknown> in your HPA instance.

answer_llm:
To resolve the 'Could not install packages due to an OSError: [WinError 5] Access is denied' error when installing libraries in Windows, you can use the `--user` option with the pip install command. For example, you can run the following command:

```bash
pip --user install grpcio==1.42.0 tensorflow-serving-api==2.7.0
```

answer_llm:
The error that occurs when running `gateway.py` after modifying the code in video 10.3 is:

`TypeError: Descriptors cannot not be created directly.`

This error indicates that the generated code is out of date and must be regenerated with `protoc >= 3.19.0`. If regeneration of protos is not immediately possible, possible workarounds include downgrading the protobuf package to version 3.20.x or lower, or setting `PROTOCOL_BUFFERS_PYTHON_IMPLEMENTATION=python`, which will use pure-Python parsing but may be slower.

question: What error occurs when running gateway.py after modifying the code in video 10.3?

answer_llm:
The TypeError: Descriptors cannot not be created directly occurs when there is an issue with the protobuf version being used. This error typically arises if you attempt to run code that relies on generated protobuf files that are out of date. If this call comes from a _pb2.py file, the generated code needs to be refreshed with protoc version 3.19.0 or higher. 

As a workaround, you can downgrade the protobuf package to a version of 3.20.x or lower, or you can set the environment variable PROTOCOL_BUFFERS_PYTHON_IMPLEMENTATION to "python", although this will result in slower performance due to using pure-Python parsing. The issue can also be resolved by specifically downgrading to protobuf version 3.20.1, which has been successful for some users.

question: What causes the TypeError: Descriptors cannot not be created directly?

answer_llm:
To resolve the issue if your generated protobuf code is out of date, you should regenerate your code using `protoc` version 3.19.0 or higher. If you cannot immediately regenerate your protos, you have a couple of workaround options:

1. Downgrade the protobuf package to version 3.20.x or lower. For example, you can run the command:
   ```
   pipenv install protobuf==3.20.1
   ```
   
2. Set the environment variable `PROTOCOL_BUFFERS_PYTHON_IMPLEMENTATION` to `python`, but keep in mind that this will use pure-Python parsing and will be significantly slower.

For more information, you can refer to the documentation at: https://developers.google.com/protocol-buffers/docs/news/2022-05-06#python-updates.

answer_llm:
To install kubectl easily on Windows, you can follow these steps:

1. Open the terminal in Visual Studio Code (using PowerShell).
2. Download kubectl using the curl command by following the instructions found in this tutorial: [Install kubectl on Windows](https://medium.com/@ggauravsigra/install-kubectl-on-windows-af77da2e6fff).
3. Specifically, you can refer to the command lines for downloading kubectl outlined here: [Install kubectl binary with curl on Windows](https://kubernetes.io/docs/tasks/tools/install-kubectl-windows/#install-kubectl-binary-with-curl-on-windows).
4. After downloading, copy the exe file to a specific folder on your C drive as mentioned in the tutorial.
5. Finally, add this folder path to your PATH in the environment variables.

This process will allow you to install kubectl on Windows efficiently.
answer_orig:
To install kubectl on windows using the terminal in vscode (powershell), I followed this tutorial: https://medium.com/@ggauravsigra/install-kubectl-on-windows-af77da2e6fff
I first downloaded kubectl with curl, with these command lines: https://kubernetes.io/docs/tasks/tools/install-kubectl-windows/#install-kubectl-binary-with-curl-on-windows
At step 3, I followed the tutorial with the copy of the exe file in a specific folder on C drive.
Then I added this folder path to PATH in my environment variables.
Kind can be installed the same way with the curl command on windows, by specifying a folder that will be added to the path environment variable.
Added by Mélanie Fouesnard

answer_llm:
To install Kind using Chocolatey (choco), follow these steps:

1. Launch a PowerShell terminal with administrator privileges.
2. Install Chocolatey by running the following command in PowerShell:
   ```powershell
   Set-ExecutionPolicy Bypass -Scope Process -Force; [System.Net.ServicePointManager]::SecurityProtocol = [System.Net.ServicePointManager]::SecurityProtocol -bor 3072; iex ((New-Object System.Net.WebClient).DownloadString('https://chocolatey.org/install.ps1'))
   ```
3. Once Chocolatey is installed, you can install Kind using the command:
   ```powershell
   choco install kind
   ``` 

Make sure to follow any additional prompts or instructions as needed.

answer_llm:
If you are having issues installing Kind through Windows Powershell and the Choco Library, you can install Kind via the Go package instead. Here’s how to do it:

1. Download and Install Go from [here](https://go.dev/doc/install).
2. Confirm your Go installation by typing `go version` in the Command Prompt.
3. Install Kind by executing the command: `go install sigs.k8s.io/kind@v0.20.0`.
4. Finally, confirm the installation by running `kind --version`.

This method works perfectly if you're facing challenges with the other installation options.

answer_llm:
To resolve the 'connection to the server localhost:8080 was refused' issue with kubectl, you can follow these steps:

1. Use the command `kind delete cluster` to delete the existing cluster.
2. Remove the kube configuration directory with `rm -rf ~/.kube`.
3. Create a new cluster by running `kind create cluster`.

After performing these steps, you should be able to use kubectl commands without encountering the connection error.
answer_orig:
I ran into an issue where kubectl wasn't working.
I kept getting the following error:
kubectl get service
The connection to the server localhost:8080 was refused - did you specify the right host or port?
I searched online for a resolution, but everyone kept talking about creating an environment variable and creating some admin.config file in my home directory.
All hogwash.
The solution to my problem was to just start over.
kind delete cluster
rm -rf ~/.kube
kind create cluster
Now when I try the same command again:
kubectl get service
NAME         TYPE        CLUSTER-IP   EXTERNAL-IP   PORT(S)   AGE
kubernetes   ClusterIP   10.96.0.1    <none>        443/TCP   53s
Added by Martin Uribe
question: How can I resolve the 'connection to the server localhost:8080 was refused' issue with kubectl?

answer_llm:
To fix the kubectl server connection issue, Martin Uribe took the following steps:

1. He deleted the existing Kubernetes cluster using the command:
   ```
   kind delete cluster
   ```

2. He removed the `.kube` directory with the command:
   ```
   rm -rf ~/.kube
   ```

3. He created a new Kubernetes cluster using the command:
   ```
   kind create cluster
   ```

After completing these steps, he was able to successfully run the command:
```
kubectl get service
```

answer_llm: To solve the issue of running out of storage after building many Docker images, you should first remove any unnecessary Docker images. After deleting the images, it's important to run the command `docker system prune`, as deleting images alone may not free up space as expected. This command will help clean up unused data, including stopped containers and unused networks, thereby freeing up storage on your instance.
answer_orig:
Problem description
Due to experimenting back and forth so much without care for storage, I just ran out of it on my 30-GB AWS instance.
My first reflex was to remove some zoomcamp directories, but of course those are mostly code so it didn’t help much.
Solution description
> docker images
revealed that I had over 20 GBs worth of superseded / duplicate models lying around, so I proceeded to > docker rmi
a bunch of those — but to no avail!
It turns out that deleting docker images does not actually free up any space as you might expect. After removing images, you also need to run
> docker system prune
See also: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/36799718/why-removing-docker-containers-and-images-does-not-free-up-storage-space-on-wind
Added by Konrad Mühlberg
question: How can I solve the issue of running out of storage after building many docker images?

answer_llm: Removing some zoomcamp directories didn't help free up space because those directories contained mostly code, which does not take up a significant amount of storage. Additionally, it turns out that simply deleting Docker images also does not free up space as expected; you must run the command `docker system prune` after removing images to actually free up that space.

answer_llm: In Kubernetes resource specifications, the "m" in CPU values like "100m" and "500m" stands for milliCPU, which is a unit of computing power. It represents one thousandth of a CPU core. For example, "100m" means the container is requesting 100 milliCPUs, equivalent to 0.1 CPU core, while "500m" indicates a CPU limit of 500 milliCPUs, equivalent to 0.5 CPU core. This unit allows for fine-grained control over CPU resources, enabling more precise expression of CPU requirements and limits for applications.
answer_orig:
In Kubernetes resource specifications, such as CPU requests and limits, the "m" stands for milliCPU, which is a unit of computing power. It represents one thousandth of a CPU core.
cpu: "100m" means the container is requesting 100 milliCPUs, which is equivalent to 0.1 CPU core.
cpu: "500m" means the container has a CPU limit of 500 milliCPUs, which is equivalent to 0.5 CPU core.
These values are specified in milliCPUs to allow fine-grained control over CPU resources. It allows you to express CPU requirements and limits in a more granular way, especially in scenarios where your application might not need a full CPU core.
Added by Andrii Larkin

answer_llm:
If your kind cluster can't find any nodes after loading a Docker image, you should specify the cluster name with the `-n` option. For example, you can use the following command:

```bash
kind -n clothing-model load docker-image zoomcamp-10-model:xception-v4-001
```
answer_orig:

Solution: Specify cluster name with -n
kind -n clothing-model load docker-image zoomcamp-10-model:xception-v4-001
Andrew Katoch

answer_llm: If you encounter the error message that "'kind' is not recognized as an internal or external command" on Windows, it may be because you downloaded the executable file with the name "kind-windows-amd64.exe". You should rename this file to "kind.exe". After renaming, place the executable in a specific folder and ensure that this folder is added to your PATH environment variable.
answer_orig:
Problem: I download kind from the next command:
curl.exe -Lo kind-windows-amd64.exe https://kind.sigs.k8s.io/dl/v0.17.0/kind-windows-amd64
When I try
kind --version
I get: 'kind' is not recognized as an internal or external command, operable program or batch file
Solution: The default name of executable is kind-windows-amd64.exe, so that you have to rename this file to  kind.exe. Put this file in specific folder, and add it to PATH
Alejandro Aponte
question: What should I do if 'kind' is not recognized as an internal or external command on Windows?

answer_llm: The error "'kind' is not recognized as an internal or external command, operable program or batch file" occurs because the default name of the downloaded executable is "kind-windows-amd64.exe." You need to rename this file to "kind.exe" and ensure it is placed in a specific folder that is included in your system's PATH.

question: Why am I getting the error 'kind' is not recognized as an internal or external command after downloading kind?

answer_llm:
To resolve the issue of 'kind' not being recognized as a command on Windows after installation, you need to follow these steps:

1. The default name of the downloaded executable is `kind-windows-amd64.exe`. You must rename this file to `kind.exe`.
2. Place the renamed `kind.exe` file in a specific folder.
3. Add the folder containing `kind.exe` to your system's PATH environment variable.

Once these steps are completed, you should be able to use the `kind` command without errors.

answer_llm:
To resolve the TypeError related to 'unbound_message' when importing Flask, you need to address the version compatibility between Flask and Werkzeug. This error typically arises when using Flask version 2.2.2 with an older version of Werkzeug (specifically 2.2.2). 

You can fix this by pinning the version of Flask to an older one. The recommended version to use is Flask==2.1.3. You can set this version by running the following command:

```
pipenv install Flask==2.1.3
```
answer_orig:
Problem Description:
In video 10.3, when I was testing a flask service, I got the above error. I ran docker run .. in one terminal. When in second terminal I run python gateway.py, I get the above error.
Solution: This error has something to do with versions of Flask and Werkzeug. I got the same error, if I just import flask with from flask import Flask.
By running pip freeze > requirements.txt,I found that their versions are Flask==2.2.2 and Werkzeug==2.2.2. This error appears while using an old version of werkzeug (2.2.2) with new version of flask (2.2.2). I solved it by pinning version of Flask into an older version with pipenv install Flask==2.1.3.
Added by Bhaskar Sarma
question: What solution can you offer for the TypeError related to 'unbound_message' when importing Flask?

answer_llm:
In video 10.3, you are encountering a TypeError "TypeError: __init__() got an unexpected keyword argument 'unbound_message'" while running `docker` and then `python gateway.py`. This issue arises due to incompatible versions of Flask and Werkzeug. Specifically, the error occurs when using an older version of Werkzeug (2.2.2) with a newer version of Flask (also 2.2.2).

To resolve this, you can pin the version of Flask to an older version. This can be accomplished by running the command `pipenv install Flask==2.1.3`. By doing this, the compatibility issue between the versions should be resolved, and you should no longer encounter the TypeError.

answer_llm:
When you encounter the error "aws: error: argument operation: Invalid choice" while using the command `aws ecr get-login --no-include-email`, you should use the `aws ecr get-login-password` command instead. 

Here’s the updated command to log in:

1. To log in with specific values:
   ```
   aws ecr get-login-password --region region | docker login --username AWS --password-stdin aws_account_id.dkr.ecr.region.amazonaws.com
   ```

2. Alternatively, if you have a default region configured:
   ```
   aws ecr get-login-password --region $(aws configure get region) | docker login --username AWS --password-stdin "$(aws sts get-caller-identity --query "Account" --output text).dkr.ecr.$(aws configure get region).amazonaws.com"
   ```

You may also follow the simplified login process by exporting the password:
```
export PASSWORD=`aws ecr get-login-password`
docker login -u AWS -p $PASSWORD <ACCOUNT_NUMBER>.dkr.ecr.<REGION>.amazonaws.com/clothing-tflite-images
```
answer_orig:
As per AWS documentation:
https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonECR/latest/userguide/docker-push-ecr-image.html
You need to do: (change the fields in red)
aws ecr get-login-password --region region | docker login --username AWS --password-stdin aws_account_id.dkr.ecr.region.amazonaws.com
Alternatively you can run the following command without changing anything given you have a default region configured
aws ecr get-login-password --region $(aws configure get region) | docker login --username AWS --password-stdin "$(aws sts get-caller-identity --query "Account" --output text).dkr.ecr.$(aws configure get region).amazonaws.com"
Added by Humberto Rodriguez

answer_llm:
The solution for the TensorFlow Serving error on an Apple M1 Mac is to use an alternative Docker image. You can pull and run the image by executing the following commands:

1. Pull the latest image:
   ```bash
   docker pull emacski/tensorflow-serving:latest
   ```

2. Run the Docker container:
   ```bash
   docker run -it --rm \
   -p 8500:8500 \
   -v $(pwd)/clothing-model:/models/clothing-model/1 \
   -e MODEL_NAME="clothing-model" \
   emacski/tensorflow-serving:latest-linux_arm64
   ```

For more information, you can refer to the GitHub page: [https://github.com/emacski/tensorflow-serving-arm](https://github.com/emacski/tensorflow-serving-arm).
answer_orig:
While trying to run the docker code on M1:
docker run --platform linux/amd64 -it --rm \
-p 8500:8500 \
-v $(pwd)/clothing-model:/models/clothing-model/1 \
-e MODEL_NAME="clothing-model" \
tensorflow/serving:2.7.0
It outputs the error:
Error:
Status: Downloaded newer image for tensorflow/serving:2.7.0
[libprotobuf FATAL external/com_google_protobuf/src/google/protobuf/generated_message_reflection.cc:2345] CHECK failed: file != nullptr:
terminate called after throwing an instance of 'google::protobuf::FatalException'
what():  CHECK failed: file != nullptr:
qemu: uncaught target signal 6 (Aborted) - core dumped
/usr/bin/tf_serving_entrypoint.sh: line 3:     8 Aborted                 tensorflow_model_server --port=8500 --rest_api_port=8501 --model_name=${MODEL_NAME} --model_base_path=${MODEL_BASE_PATH}/${MODEL_NAME} "$@"
Solution
docker pull emacski/tensorflow-serving:latest
docker run -it --rm \
-p 8500:8500 \
-v $(pwd)/clothing-model:/models/clothing-model/1 \
-e MODEL_NAME="clothing-model" \
emacski/tensorflow-serving:latest-linux_arm64
See more here: https://github.com/emacski/tensorflow-serving-arm
Added by Daniel Egbo

question: Who provided the solution for the TensorFlow Serving issue on Apple M1 Mac?

answer_llm:
If you encounter an Illegal instruction error while running the tensorflow/serving image on a Mac M2 Apple Silicon, the main solution is to switch to using the bitnami/tensorflow-serving base image. You can launch it using the following command:

```bash
docker run -d \
--name tf_serving \
-p 8500:8500 \
-p 8501:8501 \
-v $(pwd)/clothing-model:/bitnami/model-data/1 \
-e TENSORFLOW_SERVING_MODEL_NAME=clothing-model \
bitnami/tensorflow-serving:2
```

Alternatively, you can use a docker-compose.yaml configuration:

```yaml
version: '3'
services:
  tf_serving:
    image: bitnami/tensorflow-serving:2
    volumes:
      - ${PWD}/clothing-model:/bitnami/model-data/1
    ports:
      - 8500:8500
      - 8501:8501
    environment:
      - TENSORFLOW_SERVING_MODEL_NAME=clothing-model
```

Run it with:

```bash
docker compose up
``` 

This change should resolve the Illegal instruction error you are experiencing.

question: What should I do if I get an Illegal instruction error running tensorflow/serving on Mac M2 Apple Silicon?

answer_llm: Emacski's tensorflow/serving image does not work on Mac M2 primarily because it hasn't been maintained recently; the latest image is from two years ago as of December 2023. This can lead to compatibility issues, resulting in errors such as "Illegal instruction" when trying to run the image on Apple Silicon. As a solution, it is recommended to use the Bitnami TensorFlow Serving base image instead.

answer_llm:
If HPA (Horizontal Pod Autoscaler) doesn’t show CPU metrics and displays "unknown," you can try the following steps:

1. Delete the existing HPA: 
   ```
   kubectl delete hpa credit-hpa
   ```

2. Apply the metrics server configuration:
   ```
   kubectl apply -f https://raw.githubusercontent.com/pythianarora/total-practice/master/sample-kubernetes-code/metrics-server.yaml
   ```

3. Create the HPA again.

Following these steps should resolve the issue with CPU metrics reporting.
answer_orig:
Problem: CPU metrics Shows Unknown
NAME         REFERENCE           TARGETS         MINPODS   MAXPODS   REPLICAS   AGE
credit-hpa   Deployment/credit   <unknown>/20%   1         3         1          18s
FailedGetResourceMetric       2m15s (x169 over 44m)  horizontal-pod-autoscaler  failed to get cpu utilization: unable to get metrics for resource cpu: unable to fetch metrics from resource metrics API:
Solution:
-> Delete HPA (kubectl delete hpa credit-hpa)
-> kubectl apply -f https://raw.githubusercontent.com/pythianarora/total-practice/master/sample-kubernetes-code/metrics-server.yaml
-> Create HPA
This should solve the cpu metrics report issue.
Added by Priya V

answer_llm:
If you encounter errors with Istio during KServe installation, follow these steps:

1. Verify your `kubectl` version using the command:
   ```
   kubectl version
   ```
   Ensure you are using a version greater than 1.25.0.

2. Download the installation script without executing it:
   ```bash
   curl -s "https://raw.githubusercontent.com/kserve/kserve/release-0.9/hack/quick_install.sh" -o quick_install.sh
   ```

3. Edit the `quick_install.sh` file to adjust the versions of Istio and Knative as specified in the matrix on the KServe website.

4. After making the necessary changes, execute the script:
   ```bash
   bash quick_install.sh
   ```

This should resolve the issues related to Istio during the installation process.
answer_orig:
Problem description:
Running this:
curl -s "https://raw.githubusercontent.com/kserve/kserve/release-0.9/hack/quick_install.sh" | bash
Fails with errors because of istio failing to update resources, and you are on kubectl > 1.25.0.
Check kubectl version with kubectl version
Solution description
Edit the file “quick_install.bash” by downloading it with curl without running bash. Edit the versions of Istio and Knative as per the matrix on the KServe website.
Run the bash script now.
Added by Andrew Katoch

question: Are the capstone and midterm assignments solo endeavors?

answer_llm: A midterm project should generally cover topics up to module-06 of the course syllabus. It should include a well-defined problem, data preparation and exploratory data analysis (EDA), training multiple models, tuning their performance, and selecting the best model. Additionally, it involves exporting the notebook into a script, deploying the model into a web service locally with Docker, and bonus points are awarded for deploying that service to the cloud. Be sure to document any extra content that you include beyond what was covered in class.
answer_orig:
Answer: Ideally midterms up to module-06, capstones include all modules in that cohort’s syllabus. But you can include anything extra that you want to feature. Just be sure to document anything not covered in class.

answer_llm:
The deliverables for the midterm project are as follows:

1. Think of a problem that interests you and find a suitable dataset.
2. Describe the problem and explain how a model could be used to address it.
3. Prepare the data and perform exploratory data analysis (EDA), analyzing important features.
4. Train multiple models, tune their performance, and select the best model.
5. Export the notebook into a script.
6. Put your model into a web service and deploy it locally using Docker.
7. Bonus points for deploying the service to the cloud.

question: Will there be a compiled list of links to submitted projects for peer review?

answer_llm:
Emails in the peer review process for projects are hashed using the SHA-1 algorithm. To compute the hash of your email address, you can use the following Python code:

```python
from hashlib import sha1

def compute_hash(email):
    return sha1(email.lower().encode('utf-8')).hexdigest()

# Example usage
email = "YourEmail@example.com"  # Replace with your email address
hashed_email = compute_hash(email)
print("Original Email:", email)
print("Hashed Email (SHA-1):", hashed_email)
```

You need to replace "YourEmail@example.com" with your actual email address, run the code, and obtain your hashed email value. This hashed value will then help you find your assigned peer projects for review in the appropriate spreadsheet.

answer_llm:
To find the projects you need to review for the capstone, you should follow these steps:

1. **Calculate Your Hash Value**: Use the provided Python code to calculate the SHA-1 hash of your email address. This hash will help you identify the projects assigned to you for review.

2. **Review the Assigned Projects**: Once you have your hashed email, go to the Google Sheets link provided for the capstone project evaluations. You will find your hashed email value in the spreadsheet under the "reviewer_hash" heading alongside the three projects you are assigned to review.

3. **Access the Projects**: Locate the three identical entries in the spreadsheet that correspond to your hashed email, and there you will find the links to your peer projects that need to be reviewed.

Make sure to check the evaluation deadline to complete your reviews on time.
answer_orig:
I am not sure how the project evaluate assignment works? Where do I find this? I have access to all the capstone 2 project, perhaps, I can randomly pick any to review.
Answer:
The link provided for example (2023/Capstone link ): https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSdgoepohpgbM4MWTAHWuXa6r3NXKnxKcg4NDOm0bElAdXdnnA/viewform contains a list of all submitted projects to be evaluated. More specific, you are to review 3 assigned peer projects. In the spreadsheet are 3 hash values of your assigned peer projects. However, you need to derive the your hash value of your email address and find the value on the spreadsheet under the (reviewer_hash) heading.
To calculate your hash value run the python code below:
from hashlib import sha1
def compute_hash(email):
return sha1(email.lower().encode('utf-8')).hexdigest()
# Example usage **** enter your email below (Example1@gmail.com)****
email = "Example1@gmail.com"
hashed_email = compute_hash(email)
print("Original Email:", email)
print("Hashed Email (SHA-1):", hashed_email)
Edit the above code to replace Example1@gmail.com as your email address
Store and run the above python code from your terminal. See below as the Hashed Email (SHA-1) value
You then go to the link: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/e/2PACX-1vR-7RRtq7AMx5OzI-tDbkzsbxNLm-NvFOP5OfJmhCek9oYcDx5jzxtZW2ZqWvBqc395UZpHBv1of9R1/pubhtml?gid=876309294&single=true
Lastly, copy the “Hashed Email (SHA-1): bd9770be022dede87419068aa1acd7a2ab441675” value and search for 3 identical entries. There you should see your peer project to be reviewed.
By Emmanuel Ayeni

answer_llm:
To calculate your email hash for project evaluation, follow these specific steps:

1. **Prepare the Python Code:**
   Use the following Python code to compute your hashed email:

   ```python
   from hashlib import sha1
   def compute_hash(email):
       return sha1(email.lower().encode('utf-8')).hexdigest()

   # Example usage - replace 'YOUR_EMAIL_HERE' with your actual email
   email = "YOUR_EMAIL_HERE"
   hashed_email = compute_hash(email)
   print("Original Email:", email)
   print("Hashed Email (SHA-1):", hashed_email)
   ```

2. **Edit the Code:**
   Replace `"YOUR_EMAIL_HERE"` in the code with your actual email address.

3. **Run the Code:**
   Store the edited code and run it in your terminal.

4. **Retrieve the Hashed Value:**
   After running the code, you will see the output that includes your "Hashed Email (SHA-1):" value. 

5. **Access the Peer Review Spreadsheet:**
   Go to the link provided for the project evaluation spreadsheet:
   [Project Evaluation Spreadsheet](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/e/2PACX-1vR-7RRtq7AMx5OzI-tDbkzsbxNLm-NvFOP5OfJmhCek9oYcDx5jzxtZW2ZqWvBqc395UZpHBv1of9R1/pubhtml?gid=876309294&single=true)

6. **Search for Your Hash:**
   Copy your hashed email value and search for 3 identical entries in the spreadsheet under the (reviewer_hash) heading. This will show you the peer projects you need to review.

answer_llm: Instead of using `feature_importances_` in an XGBoost model, you should use the `get_score()` method if you trained the model with `model = xgb.train`.
answer_orig:
Using model.feature_importances_ can gives you an error:
AttributeError: 'Booster' object has no attribute 'feature_importances_'
Answer: if you train the model like this: model = xgb.train you should use get_score() instead
Ekaterina Kutovaia
question: What should I use instead of feature_importances_ in an XGboost model?

answer_llm: To avoid the AttributeError when accessing feature importance in XGBoost, you should use `get_score()` instead of `model.feature_importances_` if you trained your model using `model = xgb.train`. The error occurs because the 'Booster' object does not have the attribute 'feature_importances_'.
answer_orig:
Using model.feature_importances_ can gives you an error:

question: How do I avoid the AttributeError when accessing feature importance in XGboost?

answer_llm: To get feature scores when using `xgb.train`, you should use the `get_score()` method instead of `model.feature_importances_`, as the latter will lead to an error.

question: If model.feature_importances_ is not available, what can we use for feature importance in XGboost?

answer_llm: To retrieve feature importance for a Booster object in XGBoost, you should use the `get_score()` method. This is necessary because the Booster object does not have an attribute `feature_importances_`, which can lead to an AttributeError if you attempt to use it.
answer_orig:
Using model.feature_importances_ can gives you an error:

answer_llm: To avoid a pickle attribute error when using waitress with your Docker container, you should put the custom column transformer class into a separate module and import it in both the script that saves the model (e.g., train.py) and the script that loads the model (e.g., predict.py). This is necessary because when using waitress, it loads the predict_app module, which calls `pickle.load`, attempting to find the class in the global namespace. By having the class in a separate module, you ensure that it can be correctly referenced when loading the model.
answer_orig:
When running a docker container with waitress serving the app.py for making predictions, pickle will throw an error that can't get attribute <name_of_class> on module __main__.
This does not happen when Flask is used directly, i.e. not through waitress.
The problem is that the model uses a custom column transformer class, and when the model was saved, it was saved from the __main__ module (e.g. python train.py). Pickle will reference the class in the global namespace (top-level code): __main__.<custom_class>.
When using waitress, waitress will load the predict_app module and this will call pickle.load, that will try to find __main__.<custom_class> that does not exist.
Solution:
Put the class into a separate module and import it in both the script that saves the model (e.g. train.py) and the script that loads the model (e.g. predict.py)
Note: If Flask is used (no waitress) in predict.py, and predict.py has the definition of the class, When  it is run: python predict.py, it will work because the class is in the same namespace as the one used when the model was saved (__main__).
Detailed info: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/27732354/unable-to-load-files-using-pickle-and-multiple-modules
Marcos MJD
question: How can I avoid a pickle attribute error when using waitress with my Docker container?

answer_llm:
The attribute error when running a Docker container with waitress is caused by the fact that pickle cannot find the custom column transformer class in the global namespace. When the model is saved, it is stored under the __main__ module. However, when using waitress to load the model, it tries to reference that class, which no longer exists in the __main__ namespace of the predict_app module. This issue does not occur when using Flask directly because the class would be found in the same namespace when the model was saved. 

To resolve this issue, the custom class should be moved to a separate module and imported in both the script that saves the model and the script that loads the model.
answer_orig:
When running a docker container with waitress serving the app.py for making predictions, pickle will throw an error that can't get attribute <name_of_class> on module __main__.
This does not happen when Flask is used directly, i.e. not through waitress.

When using waitress, waitress will load the predict_app module and this will call pickle.load, that will try to find __main__.<custom_class> that does not exist.
Solution:
Put the class into a separate module and import it in both the script that saves the model (e.g. train.py) and the script that loads the model (e.g. predict.py)
Note: If Flask is used (no waitress) in predict.py, and predict.py has the definition of the class, When  it is run: python predict.py, it will work because the class is in the same namespace as the one used when the model was saved (__main__).
Detailed info: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/27732354/unable-to-load-files-using-pickle-and-multiple-modules
Marcos MJD
question: What causes pickle to throw an attribute error when running a Docker container with waitress?

answer_llm:
The reason pickle works with Flask but not with waitress for your custom column transformer class is due to how namespaces are handled when the model is saved and loaded. When the model was saved from the `__main__` module (e.g., using `python train.py`), the custom class is referenced as `__main__.<custom_class>`. In Flask, if you run the script directly (e.g., using `python predict.py`), the class is in the same namespace, so it works fine.

However, when using waitress, it loads a different module (the predict_app module), which means that when `pickle.load` is called, it cannot find `__main__.<custom_class>` because it doesn't exist in that context. To resolve this issue, the custom column transformer class should be placed in a separate module and imported in both the script that saves the model and the script that loads it.

Common techniques to handle outliers in a dataset include:

1. Dataset transformation (for example, log transformation)
2. Clipping high values
3. Dropping these observations

There are different techniques, but the most common used are the next:
Dataset transformation (for example, log transformation)
Clipping high values
Dropping these observations

question: Can dataset transformation help with outliers?

answer_llm: Clipping high values refers to the technique used to handle outliers in a dataset by setting a maximum limit for the values. When values exceed this predetermined maximum threshold, they are "clipped" or reduced to this maximum limit. This is often done to minimize the influence of outliers on the analysis and improve model performance.

answer_llm:
If Bento fails to import the module 'service' with a 'No module named sklearn' error, the issue may be caused by incorrectly specifying the package name in the `bentofile.yaml`. Change the package name from `sklearn` to `scikit-learn` in the packages list. Your packages section should look like this:

```yaml
packages: 
  - xgboost
  - scikit-learn
  - pydantic
``` 

This modification should resolve the error.
answer_orig:
I was getting the below error message when I was trying to create docker image using bentoml
[bentoml-cli] `serve` failed: Failed loading Bento from directory /home/bentoml/bento: Failed to import module "service": No module named 'sklearn'
Solution description
The cause was because , in bentofile.yaml, I wrote sklearn instead of scikit-learn. Issue was fixed after I modified the packages list as below.
packages: # Additional pip packages required by the service
- xgboost
- scikit-learn
- pydantic
Asia Saeed

This change should resolve the error.

answer_llm: A long error message with something about sparse matrices and a code 500 error with an empty string output in BentoML might be caused by setting DictVectorizer or OneHotEncoder (OHE) to sparse while training. If this sparse matrix is stored in a pipeline or custom object during the model saving stage in `train.py`, it can lead to inconsistent input sizes when the custom object is called in `service.py`. This is because it will convert each input to a differently sized sparse matrix, making it impossible to batch the inputs. To address this, ensure that the BentoML model signatures have `batchable` set to `False` during saving the model in `train.py`.
answer_orig:
You might see a long error message with something about sparse matrices, and in the swagger UI, you get a code 500 error with “” (empty string) as output.
Potential reason: Setting DictVectorizer or OHE to sparse while training, and then storing this in a pipeline or custom object in the benotml model saving stage in train.py. This means that when the custom object is called in service.py, it will convert each input to a different sized sparse matrix, and this can't be batched due to inconsistent length. In this case, bentoml model signatures should have batchable set to False for production during saving the bentoml mode in train.py.
(Memoona Tahira)
question: What might be the cause of a long error message with something about sparse matrices and a code 500 error with an empty string output in BentoML?

answer_llm: You get different sized sparse matrices in BentoML production when using DictVectorizer or OHE during training because if you set DictVectorizer or OHE to sparse while training and store this in a pipeline or custom object during the model saving stage, it results in each input being converted to a different sized sparse matrix when called in service.py. This inconsistency in matrix size prevents batching, leading to errors. To avoid this issue, you should set the model signatures in BentoML to have batchable set to False during the saving stage in train.py.

(Memoona Tahira)

answer_llm: To avoid errors in production when saving the BentoML model, you should set `batchable` to `False` in the model signatures. This is particularly important if you are using a DictVectorizer or One-Hot Encoder (OHE) set to sparse while training, as it can lead to inconsistent matrix sizes during batching, resulting in errors.

question: Which module should be modified to make bentoml production work if DictVectorizer or OHE is set to sparse?

answer_llm: A BentoML container could give a code 500 error with an empty string in the swagger UI if there is an issue with the handling of sparse matrices. This can occur if you have set `DictVectorizer` or `OneHotEncoder` (OHE) to produce sparse output during training, and then stored this in a pipeline or custom object when saving the model in `train.py`. When this custom object is called in `service.py`, it may attempt to convert input into varying sizes of sparse matrices, which cannot be batched due to inconsistent lengths. To resolve this, ensure that the BentoML model signatures have `batchable` set to `False` during the model saving stage in `train.py`.
answer_orig:
You might see a long error message with something about sparse matrices, and in the swagger UI, you get a code 500 error with “” (empty string) as output.
Potential reason: Setting DictVectorizer or OHE to sparse while training, and then storing this in a pipeline or custom object in the benotml model saving stage in train.py. This means that when the custom object is called in service.py, it will convert each input to a different sized sparse matrix, and this can't be batched due to inconsistent length. In this case, bentoml model signatures should have batchable set to False for production during saving the bentoml mode in train.py.
(Memoona Tahira)

answer_llm: If your model is too big for GitHub, you can try compressing the model using joblib. You can use the command `joblib.dump(model, model_filename, compress=('zlib', 6))` to compress the model, though be aware that this may take some time. Alternatively, you can use git-lfs (https://git-lfs.com/) for uploading large files to your GitHub repository.
answer_orig:
If your model is too big for github one option is to try and compress the model using joblib. For example joblib.dump(model, model_filename, compress=('zlib', 6) will use zlib to compress the model. Just note this could take a few moments as the model is being compressed.
Quinn Avila
question: What should I do if my model is too big for GitHub?

answer_llm: To compress a large model for GitHub, you can use the `joblib` library. For example, you can compress the model by using the command `joblib.dump(model, model_filename, compress=('zlib', 6))`, which will utilize zlib for compression. Keep in mind that the compression process may take some time.

answer_llm:
If you're unable to install `tflite_runtime` in a pipenv environment, it's likely because `tflite_runtime` does not run on Python 3.10. To resolve this, you should install Python 3.9, which should allow you to install `tflite_runtime` without any issues.

Additionally, you can check all available versions of `tflite_runtime` here: [TFLite Runtime Versions](https://google-coral.github.io/py-repo/tflite-runtime/). If you don't find a suitable version for your setup, consider trying options from this repository: [TFLite AWS Lambda](https://github.com/alexeygrigorev/tflite-aws-lambda/tree/main/tflite), and install a specific wheel file as demonstrated in the lecture, for example:

```bash
pip install https://github.com/alexeygrigorev/tflite-aws-lambda/raw/main/tflite/tflite_runtime-2.7.0-cp38-cp38-linux_x86_64.whl
```

If none of these solutions work, you might want to use the TFLite included in TensorFlow for local development and utilize Docker for testing in Lambda.
answer_orig:
I am getting this error message when I tried to install tflite in a pipenv environment
Error:  An error occurred while installing tflite_runtime!
Error text:
ERROR: Could not find a version that satisfies the requirement tflite_runtime (from versions: none)
ERROR: No matching distribution found for tflite_runtime
This version of tflite do not run on python 3.10, the way we can make it work is by install python 3.9, after that it would install the tflite_runtime without problem.
Pastor Soto
Check all available versions here:
https://google-coral.github.io/py-repo/tflite-runtime/
If you don’t find a combination matching your setup, try out the options at
https://github.com/alexeygrigorev/tflite-aws-lambda/tree/main/tflite
which you can install as shown in the lecture, e.g.

Finally, if nothing works, use the TFLite included in TensorFlow for local development, and use Docker for testing Lambda.
Rileen Sinha (based on discussions on Slack)

answer_llm:
If you encounter an UnidentifiedImageError while testing a model locally on a test-image data, the solution is to modify the URL of the image. You should add "?raw=true" at the end of the URL after the .jpg extension. For example, instead of using:

```python
url = 'https://github.com/bhasarma/kitchenware-classification-project/blob/main/test-image.jpg'
```

use:

```python
url = 'https://github.com/bhasarma/kitchenware-classification-project/blob/main/test-image.jpg?raw=true'
```
answer_orig:
In deploying model part, I wanted to test my model locally on a test-image data and I had this silly error after the following command:
url = 'https://github.com/bhasarma/kitchenware-classification-project/blob/main/test-image.jpg'
X = preprocessor.from_url(url)
I got the error:
UnidentifiedImageError: cannot identify image file <_io.BytesIO object at 0x7f797010a590>
Solution:
Add ?raw=true after .jpg in url. E.g. as below
url = ‘https://github.com/bhasarma/kitchenware-classification-project/blob/main/test-image.jpg?raw=true’
Bhaskar Sarma

answer_llm: If you see `[pipenv.exceptions.ResolutionFailure]` while running `pipenv install`, it means that your dependencies could not be resolved, likely due to a mismatch in your sub-dependencies. To fix this problem, manually change the `Pipfile` and `Pipfile.lock`, then run `pipenv lock`.
answer_orig:
Problem: If you run pipenv install and get this message. Maybe manually change Pipfile and Pipfile.lock.
Solution: Run: ` pipenv lock` for fix this problem and dependency files
Alejandro Aponte
question: What should I do if I see [pipenv.exceptions.ResolutionFailure] while running pipenv install?

answer_llm: Your dependencies might not resolve when using pipenv due to a mismatch in your sub-dependencies. This typically happens if you run `pipenv install` and encounter the message: "[pipenv.exceptions.ResolutionFailure]: Warning: Your dependencies could not be resolved." To fix this problem, you can manually change your Pipfile and Pipfile.lock and then run `pipenv lock`.
answer_orig:
Problem: If you run pipenv install and get this message. Maybe manually change Pipfile and Pipfile.lock.
Solution: Run: ` pipenv lock` for fix this problem and dependency files
Alejandro Aponte
question: Why might my dependencies not resolve when using pipenv?

answer_llm:
To manually change the Pipfile and Pipfile.lock to resolve dependency issues, you can follow these steps:

1. If you encounter a resolution failure message during `pipenv install`, you might need to manually adjust the Pipfile and Pipfile.lock.
2. Run `pipenv lock` to regenerate the Pipfile.lock and fix the dependency issues.
3. If you receive an error indicating that your Pipfile.lock is out of date, you can delete the Pipfile.lock using `rm Pipfile.lock` and then rebuild it by executing `pipenv lock`.
4. Alternatively, if problems persist, consider removing the pipenv environment and the Pipfile files entirely, and create new ones before trying to build again. Use the commands `pipenv --rm` and `rm Pipfile*` to do this.

By following these steps, you should be able to manually resolve dependency issues in your Pipfile and Pipfile.lock.
answer_orig:

Some free alternatives to Render for deploying a Docker image include:

1. **AWS (Amazon Web Services)** - Offers microinstances for free for a long duration and additional free resources.
2. **GCP (Google Cloud Platform)** - Similar to AWS, it provides microinstances for free along with various other free services.
3. **Saturn** - Provides free GPU instances, which can be beneficial for machine learning projects. A recent promo link is available that offers extra GPU hours for ML Zoomcamp students.

These options allow for cost-effective deployment of Docker images.

Both aws and gcp give microinstance for free for a VERY long time, and a bunch more free stuff.

answer_llm:
To convert the `day_of_the_month` and `month_of_the_year` columns into a single `day_of_the_year` column in pandas, you can follow these steps:

1. Convert the `day_of_the_month` column from int to str:
   ```python
   df['day_of_the_month'] = df['day_of_the_month'].map(str)
   ```

2. Convert the `month_of_the_year` column values (strings like 'jan', 'feb', etc.) into numerical values (1, 2, ..., 12) using the `map()` function.

3. Create a datetime object using the day and month:
   ```python
   df['date_formatted'] = pd.to_datetime(
       dict(
           year='2055',  # You can use any constant year
           month=df['month'],  # This should be the numerical month mapping
           day=df['day']  # This should be the day
       )
   )
   ```

4. Finally, extract the day of the year:
   ```python
   df['day_of_year'] = df['date_formatted'].dt.dayofyear
   ```

This will give you a `day_of_year` column containing the corresponding day of the year as an integer.
answer_orig:
Problem description: I have one column day_of_the_month . It has values 1, 2, 20, 25 etc. and int . I have a second column month_of_the_year. It has values jan, feb, ..dec. and are string. I want to convert these two columns into one column day_of_the_year and I want them to be int. 2 and jan should give me 2, i.e. 2nd day of the year, 1 and feb should give me 32, i.e. 32 nd day of the year. What is the simplest pandas-way to do it?
Solution description:
convert dtype in day_of_the_month column from int to str with df['day_of_the_month'] = df['day_of_the_month'].map(str)
convert month_of_the_year column in jan, feb ...,dec into 1,2, ..,12 string using map()
convert day and month into a datetime object with:
df['date_formatted'] = pd.to_datetime(
dict(
year='2055',
month=df['month'],
day=df['day']
)
)
get day of year with: df['day_of_year']=df['date_formatted'].dt.dayofyear
(Bhaskar Sarma)

answer_llm:
The simplest way to get the day of the year from day and month columns in pandas, according to Bhaskar Sarma, is to follow these steps:

1. Convert the `day_of_the_month` column from int to str: 
   ```python
   df['day_of_the_month'] = df['day_of_the_month'].map(str)
   ```

2. Map the `month_of_the_year` column from month names (jan, feb, ..., dec) to their respective numerical strings (1, 2, ..., 12).

3. Combine the day and month into a datetime object using:
   ```python
   df['date_formatted'] = pd.to_datetime(dict(year='2055', month=df['month'], day=df['day']))
   ```

4. Finally, extract the day of the year using:
   ```python
   df['day_of_year'] = df['date_formatted'].dt.dayofyear
   ```

answer_llm:
To transform month_of_the_year values like 'jan' and 'feb' into integers in pandas, you can use the `map()` function to convert these string values into their respective month numbers. Here’s a step-by-step guide based on the solution description:

1. First, ensure that you have a DataFrame with a column containing month names as strings (e.g., 'jan', 'feb', ..., 'dec').
2. Use the `map()` function to convert these string values to their corresponding integer values:
   ```python
   df['month'] = df['month_of_the_year'].map({
       'jan': 1,
       'feb': 2,
       'mar': 3,
       'apr': 4,
       'may': 5,
       'jun': 6,
       'jul': 7,
       'aug': 8,
       'sep': 9,
       'oct': 10,
       'nov': 11,
       'dec': 12
   })
   ```

3. After mapping the month names to integers, you can combine it with the day_of_the_month column to create a new column that represents the day of the year as integers.

This approach ensures that you accurately convert the month values from strings to integers in your DataFrame.

To format day and month columns into a datetime object using pandas, follow these steps:

1. Convert the data type of the `day_of_the_month` column from integer to string:
   ```python
   df['day_of_the_month'] = df['day_of_the_month'].map(str)
   ```

2. Convert the `month_of_the_year` column from string representations (e.g., 'jan', 'feb', etc.) to numeric representations (1 for January, 2 for February, etc.) using the `map()` function.

3. Create a new datetime column by combining the day and month columns:
   ```python
   df['date_formatted'] = pd.to_datetime(
       dict(
           year='2055',
           month=df['month'],
           day=df['day']
       )
   )
   ```

4. If needed, you can get the day of the year with:
   ```python
   df['day_of_year'] = df['date_formatted'].dt.dayofyear
   ```

question: What steps are needed to format day and month columns into a datetime object using pandas?

answer_llm:
To get the day of the year from a date formatted column using pandas, you can follow these steps:

1. Convert the `day_of_the_month` column from int to str:
   ```python
   df['day_of_the_month'] = df['day_of_the_month'].map(str)
   ```

2. Convert the `month_of_the_year` column (which contains month names as strings like 'jan', 'feb', etc.) into their corresponding month numbers:
   ```python
   df['month'] = df['month_of_the_year'].map({
       'jan': '1', 'feb': '2', 'mar': '3', 'apr': '4',
       'may': '5', 'jun': '6', 'jul': '7', 'aug': '8',
       'sep': '9', 'oct': '10', 'nov': '11', 'dec': '12'
   })
   ```

3. Create a datetime object using the day and month columns:
   ```python
   df['date_formatted'] = pd.to_datetime(
       dict(
           year='2055',  # The year can be any arbitrary year
           month=df['month'],
           day=df['day_of_the_month']
       )
   )
   ```

4. Finally, extract the day of the year:
   ```python
   df['day_of_year'] = df['date_formatted'].dt.dayofyear
   ```

This will give you the day of the year in the `day_of_year` column.

To visualize the predictions per class after training a neural net, you can follow these steps:

1. Organize your class names and predictions into a zip object.
2. Create a bar chart using `plt.bar()` to display the predictions for each class.

Here’s a sample code snippet you can use:

```python
classes, predictions = zip(*dict(zip(classes, predictions)).items())
plt.figure(figsize=(12, 3))
plt.bar(classes, predictions)
```

This will help you visualize the predictions for each class effectively.

question: What is the solution description for visualizing class predictions?

answer_llm:
To create a bar chart for predictions, follow these step-by-step instructions:

1. **Prepare your classes and predictions**: Make sure you have your classes and their corresponding predictions. You can zip them into a dictionary.
   ```python
   classes, predictions = zip(*dict(zip(classes, predictions)).items())
   ```

2. **Create a figure for the chart**: Use Matplotlib to set up the figure size for your chart.
   ```python
   plt.figure(figsize=(12, 3))
   ```

3. **Generate the bar chart**: Use the `plt.bar` function to create the bar chart with the classes on the x-axis and predictions on the y-axis.
   ```python
   plt.bar(classes, predictions)
   ```

answer_llm:
To install the CUDA toolkit and cuDNN for TensorFlow on Windows, follow these steps:

1. **Install Nvidia Drivers**: Download and install the relevant Nvidia drivers from [Nvidia's website](https://www.nvidia.com/download/index.aspx).

2. **Install Anaconda**: Download and install the Anaconda prompt from [Anaconda's website](https://www.anaconda.com/).

3. **Install TensorFlow**: You have two options:
   - Install the package `tensorflow-gpu` through Anaconda.
   - Install TensorFlow using pip as described [here](https://www.tensorflow.org/install/pip#windows-native).

4. **Install CUDA Toolkit**: Download and install the CUDA toolkit (version 11.x.x) from the [Nvidia CUDA toolkit archive](https://developer.nvidia.com/cuda-toolkit-archive).

5. **Install cuDNN**: Download and install cuDNN from the [Nvidia cuDNN download page](https://developer.nvidia.com/rdp/cudnn-download).

After completing these steps, you should be able to perform training and inference with GPU support in TensorFlow.

question: What are the steps to install the CUDA toolkit and cuDNN for TensorFlow on Windows?

answer_llm:
To install TensorFlow-GPU using Anaconda, you can follow these steps:

1. Make sure to install the Nvidia drivers from the official Nvidia website: [Nvidia Drivers](https://www.nvidia.com/download/index.aspx).
2. Install Anaconda from [the Anaconda website](https://www.anaconda.com/).
3. You have two options for installation:
   - Install the package `tensorflow-gpu` directly in Anaconda.
   - Alternatively, you can follow the TensorFlow installation method outlined at [TensorFlow's official installation guide](https://www.tensorflow.org/install/pip#windows-native) for Windows or [this link for Linux](https://www.tensorflow.org/install/pip#linux_1).
4. If you are using Linux, make sure to install CUDA by following the instructions and run:
   ```
   echo ‘export XLA_FLAGS=--xla_gpu_cuda_data_dir=$CONDA_PREFIX/lib/> $CONDA_PREFIX/etc/conda/activate.d/env_vars.sh
   ```
5. Install the CUDA toolkit (version 11.x.x) from the Nvidia developer site: [CUDA Toolkit Archive](https://developer.nvidia.com/cuda-toolkit-archive).
6. Download and install cuDNN from the Nvidia website: [cuDNN Download](https://developer.nvidia.com/rdp/cudnn-download).

Following these steps should prepare your environment for training and inference with GPU support in TensorFlow.

answer_llm:
To find help for uploading datasets on Kaggle, you can follow these steps:

1. Go to the Kaggle website and log into your account.
2. Click on your profile image and select "Account".
3. Scroll down to the API box and click on "Create New API token". This will download a `kaggle.json` file to your local machine.
4. In your notebook, create a `.kaggle` folder and upload the `kaggle.json` file there.
5. Run the command `!chmod 600 /home/jovyan/.kaggle/kaggle.json` in your notebook to set the correct permissions.
6. You can then use the command `!kaggle datasets download -d <dataset-name>` to download datasets directly from Kaggle.

For further assistance, you can refer to the relevant section on using the Kaggle API, as described in the FAQ.

answer_llm: The order is important in matrix multiplication because changing the order alters the resulting matrix. For instance, if you multiply matrix A (m x n) by matrix B (n x p), you get a matrix C (m x p). However, if you multiply B by A, you get a different matrix D (n x n). Since C and D have different sizes and typically different values, the order of multiplication is crucial, and it directly impacts the outcome of the operation.
answer_orig:
When multiplying matrices, the order of multiplication is important.
For example:
A (m x n) * B (n x p) = C (m x p)
B (n x p) * A (m x n) = D (n x n)
C and D are matrices of different sizes and usually have different values. Therefore the order is important in matrix multiplication and changing the order changes the result.
Baran Akın
question: Why is the order important in matrix multiplication?

answer_llm: If you change the order in matrix multiplication, you will get a different result. The order is important because multiplying matrix A (m x n) by matrix B (n x p) results in a matrix C (m x p), while multiplying matrix B by matrix A results in a different matrix D (n x n). C and D are matrices of different sizes and typically have different values, illustrating that changing the order affects the result.
answer_orig:

C and D are matrices of different sizes and usually have different values. Therefore the order is important in matrix multiplication and changing the order changes the result.
Baran Akın
question: What happens if I change the order in matrix multiplication?

answer_llm: The size of the resulting matrix changes with the order of multiplication. Specifically, when multiplying two matrices A (m x n) and B (n x p), the product A * B results in a matrix C of size (m x p). However, if you multiply B by A instead (B * A), the resulting matrix D will be of size (n x n). Hence, the order of multiplication is crucial, as it not only affects the outcome but also the dimensions of the resulting matrices.
answer_orig:

question: How does the size of the resulting matrix change with the order of multiplication?

answer_llm: No, multiplying matrices in a different order will not produce the same result. The order of multiplication is important in matrix multiplication; changing the order changes the resulting matrices. For example, multiplying matrix A by matrix B produces a different matrix C than multiplying matrix B by matrix A, which produces matrix D. These matrices are typically of different sizes and usually have different values.

question: Can multiplying matrices in a different order produce the same result?

answer_llm: When multiplying matrices, the order is crucial and can lead to different results and sizes of the resulting matrices. For example, if we have a matrix A of size (m x n) and a matrix B of size (n x p), multiplying them as A * B will result in a matrix C of size (m x p). However, if we change the order and multiply B * A instead, we will get a different matrix D of size (n x n). Thus, C and D not only have different dimensions but typically also different values, demonstrating that changing the order of multiplication significantly impacts the outcome.

question: Why must my GitHub repository be public for this course?

answer_llm:
To set up a Conda environment on your computer, follow these steps:

1. **Install Anaconda or Miniconda**: If you haven't installed Conda, you need to download and install Anaconda or Miniconda first.

2. **Open your terminal**: On Windows, it’s recommended to use “Anaconda Prompt.”

3. **Create a new environment**: Run the following command to create a new Conda environment:
   ```
   conda create -n ml-zoomcamp python=3.9
   ```
   This command is executed only once to create the environment.

4. **Activate the environment**: Each time you want to work on the project, activate the environment by running:
   ```
   conda activate ml-zoomcamp
   ```

5. **Export your environment (optional)**: To reproduce your environment later, you can export it to a YAML file using:
   ```
   conda env export > environment.yml
   ```
   You can recreate the environment from this file with:
   ```
   conda env create -f environment.yml
   ```

answer_llm: To resolve the error when rerunning a Docker file in Windows, specifically the error indicating that Python 3.11 is not found, you should add the Python 3.11 installation folder to your system's PATH. After making this change, restart your system and then attempt to run the Docker file again. This solution has been effective in addressing the error.
answer_orig:
When trying to rerun the docker file in Windows, as opposed to developing in WSL/Linux, I got the error of:
```
Warning: Python 3.11 was not found on your system…
Neither ‘pipenv’ nor ‘asdf’ could be found to install Python.
You can specify specific versions of Python with:
$ pipenv –python path\to\python
```
The solution was to add Python311 installation folder to the PATH and restart the system and run the docker file again. That solved the error.
(Added by Abhijit Chakraborty)

```
FROM python:3.x.x-slim
```

Replace `3.x.x` with the specific version you need.

answer_llm: Deploying to DigitalOcean App Cloud costs about 5 USD/month. The container needs to be up until the end of the project evaluation.
answer_orig:
You may quickly deploy your project to DigitalOcean App Cloud. The process is relatively straightforward. The deployment costs about 5 USD/month. The container needs to be up until the end of the project evaluation.
Steps:
Register in DigitalOcean
Go to Apps -> Create App.
You will need to choose GitHub as a service provider.
Edit Source Directory (if your project is not in the repo root)
IMPORTANT: Go to settings -> App Spec and edit the Dockerfile path so it looks like ./project/Dockerfile path relative to your repo root
Remember to add model files if they are not built automatically during the container build process.
By Dmytro Durach

answer_llm: No, it is not necessarily best to train a model only on the most important features. Any feature that can offer additional predictive value should be included. It is suggested to evaluate the model with and without certain features to see if excluding them drops performance; if it affects performance negatively, keep those features. Additionally, some important features may be highly correlated with others, and dropping some might be acceptable.
answer_orig:
I’m just looking back at the lessons in week 3 (churn prediction project), and lesson 3.6 talks about Feature Importance for categorical values. At 8.12, the mutual info scores show that the some features are more important than others, but then in lesson 3.10 the Logistic Regression model is trained on all of the categorical variables (see 1:35). Once we have done feature importance, is it best to train your model only on the most important features?
Not necessarily - rather, any feature that can offer additional predictive value should be included (so, e.g. predict with & without including that feature; if excluding it drops performance, keep it, else drop it). A few individually important features might in fact be highly correlated with others, & dropping some might be fine. There are many feature selection algorithms, it might be interesting to read up on them (among the methods we've learned so far in this course, L1 regularization (Lasso) implicitly does feature selection by shrinking some weights all the way to zero).
By Rileen Sinha
question: Is it always best to train a model only on the most important features?

answer_llm: In lesson 3.6, the example that covers Feature Importance for categorical values is related to the churn prediction project. It discusses the importance of individual features, emphasizing that some features are more important than others, as shown by the mutual information scores.

answer_llm: Could you please clarify what specific questions you have regarding the course?
answer_orig:
You can consider several different approaches:
Sampling: In the exploratory phase, you can use random samples of the data.
Chunking: When you do need all the data, you can read and process it in chunks that do fit in the memory.
Optimizing data types: Pandas’ automatic data type inference (when reading data in) might result in e.g. float64 precision being used to represent integers, which wastes space. You might achieve substantial memory reduction by optimizing the data types.
Using Dask, an open-source python project which parallelizes Numpy and Pandas.
(see, e.g. https://www.vantage-ai.com/en/blog/4-strategies-how-to-deal-with-large-datasets-in-pandas)
By Rileen Sinha
question: questions

answer_llm: Technically, yes, you can complete the course using languages like R or Scala. However, it is not advisable for several reasons: certain homework assignments require specific Python library versions, answers may not align with multiple-choice question options if you use languages other than Python 3.10 (which is the recommended version for the 2023 cohort), and your peer-reviewers may not be familiar with these languages, which could result in penalties. While you can create a separate repository using the course's lessons written in other languages for your own learning, it's not recommended for submissions.

question: What should I check if my TensorFlow Serving image doesn't test successfully after building?

answer_orig:
The TF and TF Serving versions have to match (as per solution from the slack channel)
Added by Chiedu Elue
question: What is the necessary condition for TensorFlow and TensorFlow Serving versions to work together?

answer_llm:
If the TensorFlow Serving image isn't working properly, you can troubleshoot by ensuring that the TF and TF Serving versions match, as suggested in the solution from the Slack channel. Additionally, if you are encountering issues specifically on Mac M2 or M1 Apple Silicon, consider using the Bitnami TensorFlow Serving base image or the emacski TensorFlow Serving image for better compatibility. Here are some example commands:

1. For Bitnami TensorFlow Serving:
   ```bash
   docker run -d \
   --name tf_serving \
   -p 8500:8500 \
   -p 8501:8501 \
   -v $(pwd)/clothing-model:/bitnami/model-data/1 \
   -e TENSORFLOW_SERVING_MODEL_NAME=clothing-model \
   bitnami/tensorflow-serving:2
   ```

2. For emacski TensorFlow Serving:
   ```bash
   docker run -it --rm \
   -p 8500:8500 \
   -v $(pwd)/clothing-model:/models/clothing-model/1 \
   -e MODEL_NAME="clothing-model" \
   emacski/tensorflow-serving:latest-linux_arm64
   ```

Make sure to look into these alternatives if you're facing issues with the default TensorFlow Serving image.
answer_orig:
The TF and TF Serving versions have to match (as per solution from the slack channel)
Added by Chiedu Elue
